meaning_mnemonic:
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>early</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: When the sun is above the cross, it's time for some people to go church — which is always way too early on a Sunday, am I right? Heck, on Sunday (日) even 10 a.m. (十)  is too early.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>younger brother</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: There is someone wearing horns, holding a bow, and going down a slide held up by a stick. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.

This looks like the helicopter radical with something extra under it. It's carrying some kind of cargo. Where's it headed? To <radical>Asia</radical>. You only know it's going to Asia because the cargo has a big TO ASIA label on it. (Go ahead and imagine it now.) 

I guess helicopters are the best way to deliver supplies in Asia because there are so many islands and mountains to fly between.

This looks like the shellfish radical, but a little different. It's the mighty <radical>crab</radical>! See the eyes and raised pincers at the top, the segmented belly in the middle, and the legs bunched up at the bottom? It takes some imagination, but this spiky shellfish definitely looks like a crab.

This looks like someone sitting with their back straight and a leg stretched out behind them. What kind of pose is this? Probably the kind you do in <radical>yoga</radical>. Sit on a yoga mat and make your body look like this radical. Nice, you're really doing yoga now.

Do you see the handles on the top and the barb on the bottom? It's a <radical>jackhammer</radical>. How can you tell? The two diagonal lines on the side show the motion of the jackhammer going up and down really fast, doing what jackhammers do. BBBHHRZHHHHRHHRZHZHHZH JUJUJUJUJU.

This radical consists of some legs carrying the sun out of prison. Those legs are yours. When the police stop you, though, what's your <radical>excuse</radical>? Come up with one and say it out loud, starting with, "My excuse is..."

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>together</radical>. And see how it kind of looks like two people happily sitting together arm-in-arm? These two clearly enjoy doing stuff together. They're together so much they're practically joined at the hip.

Alternatively, think of this as blackjack cards held together by fins. Fish love blackjack because the hands are usually just a few cards, so even fins can hold them together.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>beforehand</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: What does your mama tell you to do in the street? Look before you cross! You gotta do it beforehand, or it could be too late.

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>business</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: You have spikes growing out of a sheep with fins. Turn this thing into a business! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!

This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>request</radical>.

Here's a mnemonic refresher just in case: Look at the ground! You spilled some water drops, so I request that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?
See the T and F that make up this radical? Those letters stand for <radical>tofu</radical>, our favorite bean curd blocks.
